@Scamperkitty1 Solid wood, no insulation as far as I know (maybe the roof is insulated). Probably a concrete base which keeps termites away. Wood doesn't need any fire treatment (if thick enough it is a fire retardant in itself), all treatments are organic (mostly sesame seed oil).

In a 2005 Japanese experiment, 14 males aged 20-30 were given cups of cedar chips to breath over while having their systolic blood pressure measured. It started dropping after 20 seconds. Blood pressure is well known to increase during stress. https://t.co/BxsFses4Mn

In 2014, 16 Japanese students took a simple 30 minute math test in rooms with or without cedar wood interiors. The students in the non-wood rooms had elevated levels of salivary alpha-amylase, a reliable indicator of stress. The researchers attributed this mainly to smell. https://t.co/Va41k8yKWO

Humidity graph of the Motegi Junior High School. The ideal is to always be within the 40-60% range for optimal health and comfort. This is achieved without AC or humidifiers in this school built of massive wood. https://t.co/YscFvni2ng

In a 2009 study students of two schools almost identical in size but one in concrete, one in wood, were asked how spacious they felt it was. It sold quite well despite not having an ounce of violence or disease or addiction or action. It was mostly images of him as a child trying to entertain himself in odd downtown places or the peculiar ingenuities of his cash stricken parents having a go at raising kids.

It is also a supremely democratic genre. Absolutely anyone can write a book like this (obviously it is easier to sell it if your story is odd or tragic or charmed) and tons of people do. A friend of mine published a manga about his upbringing in a poor working class neighborhood.
@ReforgedSwordo Yes there are tons of weekly and monthly shows about these things. Magazines, newspaper articles. Fascinating stuff even when it is impossible to approach.
@leucasch The silliest thing I saw was playgrounds being taped over to keep kids out but somehow the tape was always ripped down come morning.

@leucasch There were no police actions, no blanket unconditional bans, people acted on their own mostly. Nothing like what I saw in other countries. We even had peaceful anti-mask and anti-vaccine demonstrations. I took many photos of them for posterity.

@leucasch Thank you. I was disgusted by what I saw in many countries (Anglophone countries especially) but we were never much affected by anything here in Japan. Our schools continued, we went to work as usual, etc. For some it was tough: bars, nightlife establishments, tourism etc.

For obvious reasons I like reading stories of how people make a decent living in some trade or business we generally assume to be impossible (like the falconer or gilt leather artist) or difficult (amateur market gardener) but wacky life choices are always fun to read about.

One of the most popular genres of literature in Japan is the "how I came to live this way" book: people explaining their chosen lifestyle or life philosophy or telling how they turned their lives around. People are endlessly fascinating, even if you'd never want to emulate them. https://t.co/EiYQm495RQ

Hand digging a well limits you to about 30m and it is hard, dangerous, work. These bamboo drillers really made agriculture and economically feasible in many new locations. Handheld drills had of course been invented but the tread wheel was a force multiplier. https://t.co/3aTRVfTrfr

It could even drill through bedrock (slower than through soil of course) and was widely used all over Japan in the 19th century to drill for hot water, geothermal, oil etc. Named after the town of Kazusa in central Chiba prefecture. It is today exported to Africa, Asia. https://t.co/yc4pUwQlLI

Kazusabori, invented in 1817 and perfected in the 1870s was a human powered bamboo well digging machine. Safe, lightweight, quick, easy to make, extremely cheap and efficient. Two persons could in a couple of months drill a 350m deep well for water or oil through. https://t.co/4jVW4Amdwe

@BillBainbridge5 Old houses were leaky and thus breathed. Moisture had a way in and a way out. The materials were hygroscopic and didn't rot as easily as out plastic wrapped modern homes. They were also built in better spots.

@BillBainbridge5 Softwood is fine the problem is that modern wood in commercial developments tend to be fast growing low density varities. There is a longevity difference. Here's two pieces of lumber. https://t.co/TQk1v294or

@Jeremyakee There are a few major differences. Both transformer kinetic or seismic energy into thermal energy but a shock absorber transfers this into a hydraulic fluid (usually). Seismic dampeners has to absorb the thermal energy itself.

@BillBainbridge5 Stone and 300 year old wood (or more) is a fantastic combination. Modern fast growing pine or fir and RC absolutely won't be around in 200 years time. As for the 90 years it is the dampener itself, the building won't last that long.

If you have a larger building your seismic dampers are considerably larger as well. Here's one covering the entire side of a building. In a large quake this building will move several feet, back and forth. https://t.co/bVqRSg8VfH

@BowTiedShrike Yes. It can be tricky as some syrphids look similar. However the bees are "fuzzier" than wasps and flies that look similar and are always "sharp". Keeping Japanese honey bees is the ultimate low/key hobby but attracting them can be really complicated. They are extremely picky.

A nest box for Japanese honey bees yields at most only one tenth of that of a Western hive, but in return it involves only two-three hours of labor per year, far far less than the intensively managed Western bees. The Japanese bees are essentially wild living. https://t.co/vOc1mkV8gw

Nearly extinct in Tokyo, I had to move across the border to Kanagawa Prefecture to finally spot a Japanese honey bee (Apis cerana japonica) in the wild. It is possible this bee is resident in a hive but most likely it is from a brood living in a hollow tree trunk nearby. https://t.co/1h9WZonXE7

In a recent survey more than half of people reported barely knowing the faces of their neighbors and two thirds reported feeling regret about this. I think we ought to revive the old system of neighborly cooperation, by hook or by crook, because the chances are, we will need it. https://t.co/N2u2Fylp65

Today this concept, 向三軒両隣, is largely gone. The last remnant being when you move into a new apartment building and give out cookies as an introduction gift to the people living around your apartment (a preemptive apology for noise and disturbances involved in moving). https://t.co/W9BCB5w97w

Childless elderly were never alone, children had plenty of playmates, housewives could share resources and burdens, husbands and fathers could devote themselves to earning their keep without worrying too much about the their families. We had each other's backs. https://t.co/A4Sa4mJZKr

After the war the concept lingered for a few decades: you could trust your neighbors with your kids if you had to work late. If someone ran out of salt for example they were expected to borrow from you. When you needed to borrow a bicycle, you could rely on your neighbors. https://t.co/g7cQSU7HqL

During the war the Mukousangen-Ryodonari turned into a civil defense role: the group was expected to take care of their own home and their neighbors, in an overlapping network of care and concern. Putting out fires, keeping firefighting equipment together, clearing roads etc.

By the early 19th century the concept of "three in front and both sides" was well established as being more than just neighbors but people you had responsibilities to, and with mutual obligations like street cleaning, child-care, aid, elderly care, security, safety, etc. https://t.co/cxhLDqC2XT

The origins of the concept is Confucian, and evolved from the old feudal system of organizing streets in groups of ten families, half of it was a "five home group", the smallest unit of feudal administration in Japan: for purposes of law, order, taxes, hygiene, water, food, etc. https://t.co/tSHTxDUTeI

In the old days (my grandparent's generation) there was a proverbial saying in Japan: 向三軒両隣, Mukosangen-Ryodonari. “The three houses in front of yours, and on both sides.“ Meaning, “these are your closest neighbors: you ought to keep close and friendly relations with them.” https://t.co/j3wVSabu6W
